TopicTitle: Amateur Telescope Making (UPDATED 9/23/18) - 20" f/4 Nearly Complete

Articles.Content: Last winter my 10in newt got frost on it, be wary about that stuff

1 hour ago, munlander1 said:

Last winter my 10in newt got frost on it, be wary about that stuff 

My 6" did and it actually had a cleaner mirror and brighter image after. Frost is pure water and thus doesn't leave spots.

59 minutes ago, _Augustus_ said:

My 6" did and it actually had a cleaner mirror and brighter image after. Frost is pure water and thus doesn't leave spots.

It was not the case for me. I still have a spot on mine

Secondary mirror is here. I have to build the holder for it (curved spider) and make a front board for the mount as the side boards bend without one.

Edited September 9, 2017 by _Augustus_

Focuser broke, have to make a new one with PVC stuff. I made a front board though. Also, one of the local astronomy clubs that I'm a member of has a ton of old ATM stuff I might get to bring home next month.....
I've decided to do the 8" mirror next instead of the 6" quartz one. Still debating focal ratio, and might even make it a Chief instead of a regular Newtonian.

1 hour ago, _Augustus_ said:

might even make it a Chief instead of a regular Newtonian.

What's the difference?

53 minutes ago, munlander1 said:

What's the difference?

A Chief uses a tilted primary mirror to avoid having a central obstruction entirely, and then uses off-the-shelf lenses to correct for the aberrations. Also known as a Jones-Herschelian. I've met the inventor of the design.

I once found a new 5" mirror on Astromart. An odd size to be sure, but it fit perfectly into the end of #10 cans, like large coffee cans. I soldered several cans together. I bought a beat up 4.5" telescope just for the focuser and secondary mirror with adjustable 45 degree holder (it was cheaper than buying those new, and I was very broke at the time). I used bicycle spokes for the spider, which the local bicycle repair shop gave me for free after I explained why I wanted what they considered trash. The bicycle spokes were a touch of genius. They have those little hex nuts that make collimation a lot easier.

I was going to add light baffling, but decided that the ribbed nature of the cans with flat black paint would be good enough. The primary mirror has a long focal length, but works quite well, especially for planets in Portland OR's light polluted skies. 

I want to grind my own mirror. The Rose City Astronomers (RCA) has a weekend shop where I can do that with expert advise. Does anyone have a recommendation on where to buy a couple of glass blanks and grinding grit?

10 hours ago, Ty Tan Tu said:

Does anyone have a recommendation on where to buy a couple of glass blanks and grinding grit?

firsthanddiscovery.com.

You only need 1 glass blank; the tool can be made with plaster/tiles.
Okay, looks like first light with the uncoated mirror will be around or shortly after the end of this month. Just have to pack up and ship my 8" SCT and order the focuser and spider for the Dob.
Well, I failed that. No one is buying the 8" SCT, so I lack funds......

I wanted to try out the motions so I built a rocker box for my Edmund 6" f/8 and put it on the f/4's base. It doesn't make it to the zenith but it should work.

UPDATE: Motions are pretty smooth. Saturn, Moon, and DSOs were pretty nice with this scope. Still have to finish the f/4.

Edited September 29, 2017 by _Augustus_
The blue 6" f/4 is going to be done by next week! I finally got a bid on my 8" SCT on eBay, so I'm going to have money! Also going to start my 8" mirror soon.

The 8" SCT is going to be out of here on Monday; as soon as that's done I can order everything - I already have the money from it but my dad won't let me spend it until I ship it out.

I'm going to be getting:

  • Destiny curved spider (already have the secondary)
  • Orion single-speed Crayford focuser
  • 38 pounds of plaster

And of course I'll have some $ left over for aluminizing.

You might be asking why I'm getting 38 lbs of plaster. The answer to that is basically because ordering in small quantities is a ripoff. For the amount needed for an 8" tool, you're paying about $2.50 per pound. If I buy 38 lbs, I'm paying about $1.42 per pound, and I don't have to order more for my next mirror.
Curved Spiders FTW!!

I ordered the parts and plaster today. I've also decided to do an 8" Dall-Kirkham as my next scope.

 

Edited October 9, 2017 by _Augustus_

Spot diagrams and specs for the Dall-Kirkham:

I have ordered the secondary/test glass blanks.

Edited October 10, 2017 by _Augustus_
Opened and installed the focuser on the 6" f/4. It's bigger than I expected.
Poured the plaster tool for the 8" DK primary.
Epoxied the tiles on the tool. Going to start rough grinding next week (need to clean up my garage floor and get a new turntable).
Garage has been cleaned up and the secondary blanks are here. Going to get started on the primary on Wednesday.
Spider for the 6" f/4 arrives tomorrow; I can star test the uncoated mirror that night!
I've started rough grinding the 8" DK primary. ROC is currently ~115" - I'm going to get it to ~90" and then switch to #120 grit.
The spider got delayed a bit in shipping, but it should arrive later today. The DK primary is now fully ground with #80 grit to an ROC of 80" or so (about 2-3" margin of error).
